article.title: Gluon shadowing and antishadowing in heavy-flavor production at the LHC

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is NOT supported by the data shown in Figure 1?
choices: Both nCTEQ15 and EPPS16 nPDFs generally agree with the experimental data for heavy-flavor production in pPb collisions.
The reweighting analysis leads to a reduction in the uncertainties of the gluon nPDF, particularly for D⁰ and J/ψ.
The LHCb B → J/ψ and Y(1S) data significantly constrain the gluon nPDFs due to their small uncertainties.
The data suggest the existence of gluon shadowing at small x, as indicated by the reweighted nPDFs being smaller than unity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the different colored bands (black, blue, green) in Figures 1(e-f) after the reweighting procedure?
choices: They represent different nPDF sets (nCTEQ15, EPPS16, and a third set).
They illustrate the impact of including different heavy-flavor data sets in the reweighting.
They reflect the uncertainty associated with different factorization scale choices (µF).
They demonstrate the variation in results obtained from different data-driven approaches.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the formula R(x,µF) = f/(Zf + Nf) represent in the context of this article?
choices: The ratio of proton PDFs to neutron PDFs.
The nuclear modification factor for parton distribution functions.
The cross-section ratio between proton-proton and proton-nucleus collisions.
The momentum fraction carried by gluons within a nucleus.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Table I provide regarding the data-driven approach used in the analysis?
choices: The x values at which gluon shadowing and antishadowing are observed.
The best-fit values for the parameters of the partonic amplitude used to model heavy-flavor production.
The uncertainties associated with different nPDF sets at various factorization scales.
The chi-squared values obtained from comparing theoretical calculations to experimental data.
